(44) 158thConclusions,Minute 1.)Air Operations.Home Theatre.Mediterranean.Pacific.naval operations.North Atlantic.MilitaryOperations.Italy.Russia.h The Chiefs of Staff reported the principal events of theprevious week.Bomber Command had flown 4^200 sorties and dropped13,000 tons of bombs on railways, oil plants and other tafgets hiGermany. Twenty bombers had been lost.United States bombers had flown 3,400 sorties and dropped7,750 tons of bombs on railways and oil installations for the lossof 70 aircraft.The Allied Expeditionary Air Force had inflicted heavy damage on. eneray movements and claimed to have destroyed900 vehicles. Enemy air activity was now almost wholly confined to the defence of Germany. Allied losses had been 14 bombers and80 fighters and fighter-bombers, as against 173 enemy aircraft destroyed.Bad weather had limited air activity and only 3,500 softies hadbeen flown and 1,000 tons of bombs dropped. Allied losses amountedto 27 aircraft as against 11 of the enemy.There had been two more attacks on Tokyo, on which 110 tonsof bombs had been dropped. The Japanese had attacked Saipan,destroying 4 Super-Fortresses and damaging 11.Shipping losses from enemy action during the mOnth ofNovember amounted to 21,584 tons. There had been no confirmedlosses so far in December.On the 27th November aircraft from H.M.S. Implacable had attacked a southbound convoy Off Rorvik, 2 ships (1 carrying troops)being sunk and 3 other ships, a trawler and an L.C.T. being seton fire.In other actions in Norwegian waters an. 8,000-ton enemy ship had probably been sunk and a number of others set on fire or damaged.There had been a slight retirement of our forces south ofArhhem, due to enemy flooding. On the 2nd Army front small. gains had been made in the Venlo area. The 9th United states army had made some small progress up to the Roer River.There had been heavy fighting on the front of the 1st UnitedStates Army opposite Cologne, where the enemy had suffered heavy casualties. In the Vosges progress had been made, and the enemy was withdrawing. The total number of prisoners since D^-dayamountedto 787*279.The weather had improved slightly and the Canadian Corpshad crossed the Ravenna-Faenza road; if this advance continued,Ravenna would be outflanked. . -The Russians had crossed the Danube south of Budapest andhad made an advance on a wide front, which threatened to outflankthe city.The War Cabinet-Took note of these statements.'NMai 2. Reference was made to the discussion in the House ofCommons on the 30th November, when some dissatisfaction had beenvoiced at the announcement by the Home Secretary and Minister ofHome Security of the War Cabinet's decision on this matter.Discussion showed the general sense of the War Cabinet to bethat, in present circumstances, the Government must retain thefullest control over such visits and that it was impossible to admit the right of every Member of Parliament to go to France. But atthe same time it might be practicable to devise a scheme whereby arepresentative party of Members of the House, possibly representingthe Anglo-French Committee, should go to France..The War Cabinet-Invited the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs and theHome Secretary and Minister of Home Security to workout a plan on these lines which should be submitted to theWar Cabinet.Civil air transport. :ChicagoConference.(previous reference:W.M. He had also suggested that aCabinet Committee should be set up to consider our policy in Burma.The Prime Minister suggested that the India committee under the Chairmanship of the Lord President of the Council,reinforced as might be necessary by any Minister specially con-cerned, should be invited to consider the general issue of policy in burma and to report to the War Cabinet; and that meanwhile theSecretary of State for Burma should be authorised to say in the debate on the 8th December that Burma policy was receiving active consideration.The War Cabinet-Agreed with the Prime Ministers suggestion.Foreign Affairs; 10. The War Cabinet agreed that,on the amendment about the eaiport trade and the' industrial change-over-from war to peace, the Ministerof Production should make a statement in the name ofthe War Cabinet to the effect that war production must continue to have absolute priority over all other formsof production.i The Minister of Production undertook to prepare a draft in consultation with the Minister of Labour and, National Service and the President of the Board ofTrade and submit it to the Prime Minister.(3) Thursday, 7th December. The War Cabinet were informed that there was strong pressure in Parliament for a public statement on this matter. thus a motion had been put down in the House of Lords by Lord Portsea,and there was a question for answer by the Home Secretary and minister of Home Security on the 7th December.The general view of the War Cabinet was that, if any public statement was made at the present time, it would have ahunfortunate effect on the negotiations with the German government now being conducted through the Protecting Power.The War Cabinet decided that, if it was impossible to securethe withdrawal of the question and of the motion, any reply at thepresent time should not go beyond saying that the matter wasunder consideration, that it would not be in the public interest tomake a full statement on the matter at this juncture, and that itwas hoped that enquiries would not be pressed.Newfoundland.Lord Ammon'sPamphlet.(previous reference:W.M. At the meeting of the War Cabinet on the 30th november the hope had been expressed that it would be possible to secure the postponement of the questions put down by Sir D. Gunston andMr. A. P. Herbert.The Secretary of State for Dominion Affairs informed theWar Cabinet that he had now been able to secure the postponement of these questions until Newfoundland next came up for debate inthe House of Commons.The War Cabinet-Took note of this statement."Offices of the War Cabinet, S.W. 1,4th December, 1944.11. At their meeting on the 8th November the War cabinet had agreed that a Committee, comprising persons with expertknowledge of electoral machinery, should be appointed to deviseand submit to the War Cabinet at an early date a scheme for postalvoting for the forces.The question had since been raised as to who should preside over this Committee. The Home - Secretary and Minister of home security had pointed out that political issues were involved and had suggested that it might be more appropriate that the Committeeshould, be presided over by some independent person than by a minister of the Crown.On the other hand, it had been suggested that, in view of thecircumstances of the present enquiry, the balance of advantage layin having as Chairman a War Cabinet Minister.After a short discussion, the War Cabinet-Invited the Chancellor of the Exchequer to undertake theduty of presiding over the Committee.
